humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: In terms of font, the oracle " He " is a full-character pictogram as Luo Zhenyu said: "Upper like spike and leaf. Lower like stem and root." Many scholars later agreed with this theory, such as Xu Zhongshu, Gao Hongjin, Chen Mengjia , Li Xiaoding, Chen Weizhan, etc.

Qiu Xigui has a brief analysis of the distinction between the three characters " He ", " Millet " and " Lai " in the oracle bone inscriptions. He pointed out that millet (that is, " He was") poly and drooping ear shape, ear millet is scattered, and wheat (note: ie Oracle, " to ") is straight on the ear. It can be seen that the oracle bone inscriptions mainly distinguish the three by the difference of the ear shape. The characters " He " in bronze and small seal roughly inherit the shape of oracle bones.

" Wo " with the meaning of terms, various companies have pointed out inscriptions " Wo ", " annual " general situation (such as Guo, Seigo, Meng home, Xiao Yao then, Qiu Xigui, etc.). Among them, two scholars, Yao and Qiu, put forward their opinions worthy of reference on the relationship and usage of the two characters. " Wo ", " in " is when there are inscriptions in general, but with different words, and " Wo " nor " years " of the province write (Yan Yiping think " Wo " to " On " province-shaped). " In the beginning of righteousness" is (Valley cooked) harvest, the idea was "aged" righteousness. " On " from the word " Wo " has been showing in the ancient millet is an important crop. Mr. Qiu specifically pointed out that in addition to inscriptions on "Shou Nian", he also asked "Shou Nian" many times. But no question about "Shouhe Year" was seen. Mr. Qiu believes that this should be because the amount of gras planted far exceeds that of other grains. Asking whether to accept the year or not is to ask whether the year is to be accepted, so there is no need to inquire about it. In addition, Xiao Yao then considered " Wo " when used as a general sense (refers to all cereals), at all "by Wo" or "by years." When referring specifically to a certain kind of grain, it is said to be "received for a certain year" (such as "received millet year") instead of "received for a certain grain."

There are the following types of use cases for inscriptions (refer to "General Explanation of Inscriptions and Meanings" for the first three items). 1. Refers to grains, such as the Ding Ding: "In the past, Kuang Zhonglu (jue) ministers twenty husbands Kou He Shi Zi." humanum_short_description_en: The whole word " He " in the oracle bone inscription is like a whole plant of cereals (ie millet). The original meaning is cereals, and it refers to all grains in general.
